data.title: Chromosomal crossover
data.statement:
Genetic algorithms are a class of algorithms inspired by the process of natural selection. One of the main step of these algorithm is the crossover - the action of crossing two chromosomes. 
The goal of this exercise is to implement such mechanism.

A chromosome is a list of numbers. The input will also define up to 20 crossing points. 
To cross two chromosomes, you have to consider the part of chromosome 1 until the first crossing point, then the part of the chromosome 2 between the first and second crossing point, then the part of chromosome 1 between the second and third crossing point and so on. The second child is obtained by taking first chromosome 2, then 1, then 2 again.

In the first example below, we use one crossing point <<2>>, one chromosome <<1 2 3 4>> and <<5 6 7 8>>, for the first child chromosome:
- I take the first <<2>> numbers of chromosome 1 : <<1 2>>,
- Then I take the last numbers of chromosome 2: <<7 8>>,
- Which makes <<1 2 7 8>>.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Genetic algorithms are a class of algorithms inspired by the process of natural selection. One of the main step of these algorithm is the crossover - the action of crossing two chromosomes.
The goal of this exercise is to implement such mechanism.

A chromosome is a list of numbers. The input will also define up to 20 crossing points.
To cross two chromosomes, you have to consider the part of chromosome 1 until the first crossing point, then the part of the chromosome 2 between the first and second crossing point, then the part of chromosome 1 between the second and third crossing point and so on. The second child is obtained by taking first chromosome 2, then 1, then 2 again.

In the first example below, we use one crossing point 2, one chromosome 1 2 3 4 and 5 6 7 8, for the first child chromosome:
- I take the first 2 numbers of chromosome 1 : 1 2,
- Then I take the last numbers of chromosome 2: 7 8,
- Which makes 1 2 7 8.
Input
First row: all the crossing points separated by space
Second row: first chromosome - with numbers separated by space
Third row: second chromosome - with numbers separated by space
Output
First row: first child chromosome - with numbers separated by space
Second row: second child chromosome - with numbers separated by space
Constraints
1 ≤ number of crossing points ≤ 20
4 ≤ chromosome 1 size = chromosome 2 size ≤ 100
Example
Input
2
1 2 3 4
5 6 7 8
Output
1 2 7 8
5 6 3 4
